Plan to determine the blocks A collides with and where it will stop based on power, collision, and deflection effects.

The car 'A' is coming from the right side of the scene. Several blocks are scattered in front of the car, including blocks of various colors (yellow, red, green, blue, orange) and a marble. The blocks are arranged in different configurations, some stacked and some placed on the flat surface.

The car is moving from the right towards the center where the blocks are arranged. The direction of motion is from right to left. The position and velocity of the car will determine the direction and intensity of its collisions with the blocks.
The car is likely to first collide with the stack of yellow and red blocks that are positioned directly in front of it.
The car will likely transfer enough force to move some of the yellow and red blocks, especially if they are not heavily stacked.
Depending on the angle of impact, the yellow and red blocks could either shift slightly or be displaced entirely, particularly the yellow blocks, which appear to be the closest.
The blue stack and red block (to the left of the yellow blocks) may also be impacted by the car’s motion if the car is moving at an angle after hitting the initial yellow blocks.
The impact on the blue stack and red block will depend on how much of the car’s energy is transferred upon impact, as well as the relative mass of the blocks.
The blue blocks, especially if they are stacked higher, may cause the car to deflect slightly to the left or right.
The orange block, which is at the far right of the scene, may either remain unaffected or be nudged slightly, depending on the final deflection of the car after hitting other blocks.
The car will likely stop in a position where its forward momentum is largely dissipated.
